scarcely.translation[0].definitions[0].d: almost not or almost none at all
scarcely.translation[0].definitions[0].e: The city had scarcely changed in 20 years.
The country had scarcely any industry.
He scarcely ever left the region.
Scarcely a day goes by when I don’t think of him.
It was getting dark and she could scarcely see in front of her.
scarcely.translation[0].definitions[1].e: He had scarcely sat down when there was a knock at the door.
scarcely.translation[0].definitions[2].d: definitely not or almost certainly not
scarcely.translation[0].definitions[2].e: Early March is scarcely the time of year for sailing.
scarcely.translation[0].note_box[0].item: Scarcely usually comes before a main verb
Scarcely comes after the first auxiliary verb
I can scarcely believe he said that
I scarcely can believe he said that
Scarcely usually comes after the verb ‘be’ when it is used in simple tenses such as ‘is’ or ‘was’
I was scarcely aware of the noise
You can use scarcely at the beginning of a sentence before an auxiliary, to emphasize that one thing happens very soon after another thing
Scarcely had they left the station than the train stopped
